posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: My team has an elevator that can reach up to Level 3, but we are considering upgrading its height to Level 4 to achieve the net. What steps can we take to accomplish this? One idea that has come to mind is adding stages to the elevator, though I am still unclear on how effective this approach will be. Currently, we utilize an SDS elevator.

posts.name: Sameer
posts.cooked: The term "stages" in the context of elevators generally refers to the number of segments or components that make up the elevator's mechanical system. These stages include elements such as pulleys, ropes, and motor-driven sheaves. The exact number of stages can vary significantly based on the elevator's design, purpose, and technical specifications. Factors like the type of driving mechanism (e.g., screw-driven, gear-driven, or traction motor-driven), the building's height, weight capacity, and age all play a role in determining the number of stages. Therefore, to precisely determine the number of stages in a particular elevator, detailed information about the elevator's specific characteristics would be necessary.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked:
The text is:  
"I’m assuming that the smallest, innermost stage of the elevator has your scoring mechanism on it. If you were to place the scoring mechanism higher up on that stage (or make a little structure to extend your stage if it’s very small, and put it on that), it doesn’t change the total height of the elevator when all the way down, but when all the way up, the scoring mechanism will be higher off the ground."

posts.name: hrench
posts.cooked: If you’re still playing robots on April 8, you’re likely heading to the championship. To excel there, you’ll need an advanced robot, likely capable of Level 4 performance. Without such a robot, it’s unlikely any team would choose yours over more polished options, especially from well-known alliances. Continuously improving your robot throughout the season is crucial—identify areas it can excel in or improve upon and start addressing those issues. However, inertia can be a significant obstacle, as students are often preoccupied with prom, jobs, or seasonal activities. Despite these distractions, improving to Level 4 is essential if you aim to perform well at the championship. While personal input isn’t mandatory, if your goal is to win, seriously consider upgrading your robot. If you’re focused solely on fun, consider the downside of losing. In 2012, we were ranked 100th out of 100 in Galileo, and not fixing our issues left us discouraged. Back then, limited access to practice bots made it difficult to test and refine our design, a challenge we could overcome today.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Bob Hrenchir, mechanical build mentor, team 1108, Paola, KS

posts.name: Andrew
posts.cooked: I don't know if you're going to CHAMPS or not, so I'll make a list for both. If you are going to CHAMPS, I would recommend not upgrading the elevator. While L4 and Barge are somewhat of a necessity at Worlds to do well, the time it takes at the current moment of writing this is quite small. Adding a new stage to lengthen your elevator is quite risky—you would have to manufacture new parts, maybe buy new parts, and handle wiring and possibly programming as well. There are too many factors that need to be worked on, so even if you get the elevator done, your robot could be inconsistent due to rushing, and inconsistency is often looked down upon in alliance selections. Instead, I would recommend trying to improve existing parts and autos, aiming to get what you already do to a more consistent level—having each one run around 10-12 times without breaking or with a negligible amount of error. This can offset any luck needed to do well at CHAMPS. If you are not going to CHAMPS, it's up to you. Not doing the elevator upgrade can save you time to do other things outside of robotics and also conserve parts for next year. However, doing the elevator upgrade can prove to be a great offseason project to get new or existing members acquainted with new skills.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5013 Pit Crew and Design (I do not speak for my team, just my opinions)

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: Our team reached the state level but did not advance to the world championships. These are some potential modifications we might consider for the upcoming Invitational competition in October. I'm just brainstorming ways to improve our scoring at that event.

posts.name: Mahir
posts.cooked: We have three, but we have resolved the issue. We simply need to acquire longer aluminum tubing to elevate the system since all other components are already in place.

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked: It looks like you have a 2-stage elevator, so you'd need to extend the height of both stages. I think your carriage can probably stay the same, which preserves the geometry of the funnel handoff to the end effector.
